For the analogy the rich are like a goat or cow, you milk them. And a good milk farm rancher will tell you, they set up their machines so the cow actually goes to get itself milked of its own volition and they never take too much as to render the cow dry, they take a controlled and limited amount. Nor do they starve the cow, deny it care and space to do its own thing, and of course they don't kill a milk producing cow.

A Marxist will always kill the cow, and the socialist always considers killing the cow as step two. And if you want to be profitable, having more cows, as long as your feed and space can support them is always preferable. In this analogy's case the feed would be a work force, and space would be area they can develop in.

replies.author: @NineNovem
replies.text:
A townhouse? To raise *kids?* Dude, there's not very many places in my area that get broken into *more* than townhouses, and I live in the middle of feckin' nowhere Gunland where people generally know that if they screw up hard enough, they'll catch a bullet from Grandma Helen, Grandpa Joe, and all 6 of their kids at the same time. 

If you have *any* choice, a townhouse is not gonna be your first home. You get a single story house, and if you need the extra space, you sell that and get a bigger house. Hopefully one that's as far away from the city as you can get without being *so* far away that the nearest grocery store is an hour up the road.

replies.author: @chubbbubb6870
replies.text: ‚Äã@NineNovemmy dad was the youngest of 16 kids. They had a dirt floor in their home for a couple years. They wore hand me downs donated by the local church. My dad never had a new pair of shoes until he joined the army. I'm not saying we should go back to this. I'm just pointing out that people used to have way more kids despite being much much poorer.

replies.author: @NineNovem
replies.text:
‚Äã@chubbbubb6870Very humble origins. I can respect that!  I've got a platoon of aunts and uncles myself, so I know *that* whole deal. Though, with how much more "stable" things were socially (particularly in relationships), we were more willing to stick it out together even if times were hard. 

If more people still had that mindset instead of saying "I'm not happy. Adios!" the second things got a bit dicey, there'd be more incentive to get married and have a bunch of kids because you'd likely get to keep em' instead of ending up in a Kenmore box. Nowadays? Especially with the way the laws are? No way, man. Not worth the risk.

author: @TheNotimprezed
text: NY already had paid family leave, 12 weeks.  It didn't exist when we had our first kid, but was there for my 2nd and 3rd.  The problem is the tax caps at $172/year. The max payout is $972/week, which you hit if you earn about $100k.  So the 24 weeks I took cost the taxpayer about $24k. It will only take the state 135 years to collect enough from me to break even, and another 135 years to break even from the 24 weeks my wife used as well (she also qualified for the max $972/week at the time)

author: @danieldow9385
text:
I lived in a rent-controlled apartment in San Francisco with my wife and two children and I was so thankful for that rent stabilization. It only cost us $3500 a month for that two bedroom and market rates would have been closer to $5000.

Now, I live in Florida in a three bedroom house and I have to pay $3100 a month for my mortgage. I sit and cry on the shore of the 11 square mile natural lake that site 10 yards outside my backdoor because I miss all the poop I used to see on the street in San Francisco. I also miss sitting with my front door open any time I was waiting for a delivery because I used to get so much exercise racing to the package to make sure I grabbed it before one of the 700 homeless people encamped up and down my street grabbed it.

Such is life.

author: @biostemm
text: Rent control/rent stabilization doesn't suddenly make the costs to improve or even just properly maintain those properties any more affordable.  Sure, there are slumlords who exploit their tenants, but the pendulum has swung too far in the other direction;  It's so difficult to evict a legitimately deadbeat tenant, and law enforcement isn't there to properly prevent or deter damage and vandalization.  Further, there is so much red tape and corruption in the process of building new homes that it isn't feasible, either...

author: @grant28304
text: I'm glad someone else noticed the BS around family leave policies and claiming they will boost family formation. At best you can say it has no effect but more likely it actually makes things worse.

replies.author: @grant28304
replies.text: One of my hypothesis is that these kinds of policies make things worse because the more you disconnect women's choices in men away from traits that make men reliable the worse choices women make in men. And that eventually makes them jaded on men or put off trying to start a family to late. Put another way, if a woman has to rely on a man when she has children she now has to weigh traits like stability, reliability, loyalty and kindness more than traits like hot, sexy, tall, exciting, and mysterious (or also bad boy traits).

author: @jeffreyterwilliger3089
text: I've been in Raleigh for 35 years. Every single year has seen unrelenting influx. The public roads look just like DC, in a state of constant expansion and repair (in addition to repairs of large-scale contractor fraud over that time). We are seeing the turnover of 1/2 acre lots from single homes to 3-story, 12 unit condos and rentals at an accelerating rate (with 2-lane streets turning into literal parking lots). Free market? Good. Planning for traffic, schools and support infrastructure? ALWAYS behind to curve. What is the solution? Not many know, but it will take much better brains than what NYC and Seattle are getting. However, they all seem to be coming here with the same old ideas in mind.
